newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs track Wall St, end up in strong trade.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs track Wall St, end up in strong trade.

text.p: Brazilian stocks tracked Wall Street to close firmly higher on Monday in heavy trade amid rising options-related volatility and led by climbing electrical shares, brokers said.
"There was really no news today. We had activity in Telebras and second-tier shares, but trading was calm," a local trader told Reuters.
The Sao Paulo bolsa's Bovespa index of 48 most-traded shares ended up 0.55 percent at 11,334 points on volume totalling 761.3 million reais ($709 million).
Brokers said Monday's trend was set by Wall Street and bellwether Telebras, whose benchmark preferred rose to 149.80 reais before slipping back to close at 147.80 reais for a rise of 0.75 percent.
Its common ended up 0.35 percent at 138.99 reais.

Rises in New York prompted a parallel surge in Sao Paulo early in the day, but the market was later hit by profit-taking, which some dealers expect will continue Tuesday on an absence of market-moving news.
"The market has a lot of fat that can come off," one broker said.
Brokers said the market began to show some volatility ahead of June 16 options expiration.
Apart from Telebras, the bolsa also saw healthy rises in other blue chips, including state oil firm Petrobras and mining giant Cia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD).
Petrobras preferred rose 1.93 percent to 265.00 reais while CVRD's preferred jumped 2.16 percent to close at 23.60 reais.
The bolsa's Electrical Energy Index of nine most-traded power stocks closed up a strong 2.33 percent at 3,000 points on positive outlooks for the sector's privatization.

Eletrobras preferred rose 0.59 percent to 515 reais while preferred shares of Sao Paulo state power firm Cia Paulista de Forca e Luz (CPFL), one of the first Brazilian electrical utilities expected to be sold off, surged 6.09 percent to end at 157.01 reais.
